title: Impressum
body:
This content was developed by the Emerging Technologies for the Circular Economy Lab (ETCE LAB) at Clausthal University of Technology, Germany. 

The course is modeled and built based on the book "Requirements Engineering â€“ Fundamentals, Principles and Techniques" (link) by Klaus Pohl. Special thanks to Prof. Dr. Steffen Herbold and Dr. Christian Bartelt, who provided valuable input in the form of the teaching materials of their requirements engineering courses.

We are committed to make all of our teaching material available to the public. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License. Feel free to use it for your own purposes. Please share it widely.

title: Question 1
body: Question 1: Which type of communication usually relies heavily on redundancy and allows for allow for the possibility of immediate feedback?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_feedback.correct: The correct answer is: "verbal communication". While "written communication" also relies on redundancy to some extent, it doesn't typically provide immediate feedback in the same way that oral communication does. In written communication, feedback is often delayed, depending on when the receiver reads and responds to the message.

_incorrect.final: The correct answer is: "verbal communication". While "written communication" also relies on redundancy to some extent, it doesn't typically provide immediate feedback in the same way that oral communication does. In written communication, feedback is often delayed, depending on when the receiver reads and responds to the message.

title: Question 02
body: Question 02: Categorise the following into Functional and Quality requirements.
instruction: Choose an option from each dropdown list and select Submit.

_items.text: User must provide either email or phone number when submitting a complaint.
User must accept GDPR compliance policy on complaint submission form.
Native notification API's should be used if possible.
Complaint notifications should not take more than 1 minute.
Email field should only contain one '@' character.
Administrators should be notified when User submits a complaint.
User interface should be touch-screen friendly.

_feedback.correct:
Your answer is correct.

 

  • A functional requirement is a requirement concerning a result of behavior that shall be provided by a function of the system
  • A quality requirement is a requirement that pertains to a quality concern that is not covered by functional requirements

_incorrect.final:
Your answer is incorrect.

  • A functional requirement is a requirement concerning a result of behavior that shall be provided by a function of the system
  • A quality requirement is a requirement that pertains to a quality concern that is not covered by functional requirements

title: Question 3
body: Question 3: The system boundary...
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: ... defines the scope of the requirements engineering process.
... defines the scope of the developement.

_feedback.correct: The correct answer is "The system boundary defines the scope of the development." This answer accurately reflects the role and significance of a system boundary in defining the extent of work in a system development project. It is not limited to the requirements engineering process but encompasses the entire development lifecycle.

_incorrect.final: The correct answer is "The system boundary defines the scope of the development." This answer accurately reflects the role and significance of a system boundary in defining the extent of work in a system development project. It is not limited to the requirements engineering process but encompasses the entire development lifecycle.

title: Question 04
body: Question 04: Place the following software testing phases in their correct order.
instruction: Choose an option from each dropdown list and select Submit.

_feedback.correct:
The correct order of software testing levels is as follows:

  1. Unit Testing: Testing individual code components.
  2. Integration Testing: Testing how components work together.
  3. System Testing: Testing the entire system.
  4. Acceptance Testing: Ensuring the system meets user requirements.

_incorrect.final:
The correct order of software testing levels is as follows:

  1. Unit Testing: Testing individual code components.
  2. Integration Testing: Testing how components work together.
  3. System Testing: Testing the entire system.
  4. Acceptance Testing: Ensuring the system meets user requirements.

title: Question 09
body: Question 09a: In the context of UML Class Diagrams, which UML relations notation represents the UML relation "composition"?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_feedback.correct: Composition (Filled Diamond): Composition is similar to aggregation but indicates a stronger relationship. It is represented by a filled diamond shape. In this case, the parts are inseparable from the whole. If the whole is destroyed, the parts are also destroyed. It represents a stricter form of containment.

_incorrect.final: Composition (Filled Diamond): Composition is similar to aggregation but indicates a stronger relationship. It is represented by a filled diamond shape. In this case, the parts are inseparable from the whole. If the whole is destroyed, the parts are also destroyed. It represents a stricter form of containment.

title: Question 09
body: Question 09b: In the context of UML Class Diagrams, which UML relations notation represents the UML relation "aggregation"?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_feedback.correct: Aggregation (Hollow Diamond): Aggregation is depicted using a hollow diamond shape on one end of the association line. It represents a "whole-part" or "has-a" relationship. This means that one class (the whole) is composed of or contains instances of another class (the part). Importantly, the parts can exist independently of the whole.

_incorrect.final: Aggregation (Hollow Diamond): Aggregation is depicted using a hollow diamond shape on one end of the association line. It represents a "whole-part" or "has-a" relationship. This means that one class (the whole) is composed of or contains instances of another class (the part). Importantly, the parts can exist independently of the whole.

title: Question 16
body: Question 16: A new machine learning model is being developed in Python using Numpy, PyTorch and Matplotlib libraries. Categorize the following based on which boundary they strictly lie within:
instruction: Choose an option from each dropdown list and select Submit.

_feedback.correct:
â€œThe system boundary separates the system to be developed from the system
context. The system boundary separates the parts that belong to the system and
can hence be changed during the development process from the parts of the
system context that cannot be changed during the development process.â€

The correct answers are:
The machine learning library â†’ System Boundary
Numpy â†’ Context Boundary
Pytorch â†’ Context Boundary
Matplotlib â†’ Context Boundary

_incorrect.final:
â€œThe system boundary separates the system to be developed from the system
context. The system boundary separates the parts that belong to the system and
can hence be changed during the development process from the parts of the
system context that cannot be changed during the development process.â€

The correct answers are:
The machine learning library â†’ System Boundary
Numpy â†’ Context Boundary
Pytorch â†’ Context Boundary
Matplotlib â†’ Context Boundary

title: Question 17
body: Question 17: Which of the following requirements are problematic (inadequate, inconsistant or ambiguous)?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Page should redirect automatically to user's home page after login.
Email and Phone fields are mandatory.
This page should allow users to upload .odt or .pdf files
Some users should not be able to access this page.

_feedback.correct:
The correct answers are:

"This page should allow users to upload .odt or .pdf files" â€“ ambiguous use of 'or' (exclusive or inclusive 'or')! Does not specify if each user can only upload one file either .odt or .pdf, or if every user
can upload as many .odt and .pdf files.

"Some users should not be able to access this page."  â€“ Does not specify
which users!

_incorrect.final:
The correct answers are:

"This page should allow users to upload .odt or .pdf files" â€“ ambiguous use of 'or' (exclusive or inclusive 'or')! Does not specify if each user can only upload one file either .odt or .pdf, or if every user
can upload as many .odt and .pdf files.

"Some users should not be able to access this page."  â€“ Does not specify
which users!

title: Question 09
body: Question 09c: In the context of UML Class Diagrams, which UML relations notation represents the UML relation "inheritance"?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_feedback.correct: Inheritance (Solid Line with Hollow Arrowhead): Inheritance, or generalization, is shown as a solid line with a hollow arrowhead pointing from the subclass (child) to the superclass (parent). This notation indicates an "is-a" or "kind-of" relationship, where the subclass inherits attributes and behaviors from the superclass.

_incorrect.final: Inheritance (Solid Line with Hollow Arrowhead): Inheritance, or generalization, is shown as a solid line with a hollow arrowhead pointing from the subclass (child) to the superclass (parent). This notation indicates an "is-a" or "kind-of" relationship, where the subclass inherits attributes and behaviors from the superclass.

title: Question 09
body: Question 09d: In the context of UML Class Diagrams, which UML relations notation represents the UML relation "dependency"?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_feedback.correct: Dependency (Dashed Line with Arrowhead): Dependency is represented by a dashed line with an arrowhead pointing from the dependent class to the class it depends on. This notation indicates that one class relies on another class or uses it in some way. Dependencies can arise when one class uses another class as a parameter or local variable, but it's a weaker relationship compared to associations.

_incorrect.final: Dependency (Dashed Line with Arrowhead): Dependency is represented by a dashed line with an arrowhead pointing from the dependent class to the class it depends on. This notation indicates that one class relies on another class or uses it in some way. Dependencies can arise when one class uses another class as a parameter or local variable, but it's a weaker relationship compared to associations.

title: Question 09
body: Question 09e: In the context of UML Class Diagrams, which UML relations notation represents the UML relation "association"?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_feedback.correct: Association (Solid Line): An association in UML is represented by a solid line connecting two classes. It signifies a basic relationship between these classes, often indicating that instances of one class are connected or associated with instances of the other class. An optional arrowhead can indicate the direction of the relationship, showing which class knows about the other.

_incorrect.final: Association (Solid Line): An association in UML is represented by a solid line connecting two classes. It signifies a basic relationship between these classes, often indicating that instances of one class are connected or associated with instances of the other class. An optional arrowhead can indicate the direction of the relationship, showing which class knows about the other.

title: Question 09
body: Question 09f: In the context of UML Class Diagrams, which UML relations notation represents the UML relation "realization/ implementation"?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_feedback.correct: Realization (Solid Line with Hollow Triangle): Realization is used to show that a class implements the methods and behaviors defined by an interface or abstract class. It is represented by a solid line with a hollow triangle at the interface or abstract class end. It illustrates that the implementing class fulfills the contract defined by the interface.

_incorrect.final: Realization (Solid Line with Hollow Triangle): Realization is used to show that a class implements the methods and behaviors defined by an interface or abstract class. It is represented by a solid line with a hollow triangle at the interface or abstract class end. It illustrates that the implementing class fulfills the contract defined by the interface.

title: Slide Set on Github

title: Lecture Content
body:
In this lecture, you will find out why Requirements Engineering (RE) is essential for software and systems engineers, get an overview of what it is and what the different steps of the process entail. The lecture is structured into three main parts, each focusing on a crucial aspect of Requirements Engineering:

1. Motivation for Requirements Engineering
In this first part, we will delve into the motivations behind Requirements Engineering. You'll gain insight into why RE is a critical phase in software development. Understanding the reason for RE will set the stage for grasping its importance in the software engineering and IT domains.

2. Requirements Engineering Overview
In the second part of the lecture, we will provide an overview of Requirements Engineering. This segment serves as a foundational introduction to the fundamental concepts, terminology, and principles of RE. You'll learn what constitutes a requirement, the different types of conditions, and the role they play in shaping the software development process. This overview will help you establish a solid understanding of the fundamental building blocks of RE.

3. Requirements Engineering Process
The final part of our lecture will dive deep into the Requirements Engineering process itself. We will break down the steps and methodologies involved in effectively gathering, analysing, documenting, and managing requirements. You'll gain a practical understanding of how to navigate the RE process, ensuring that conditions are well-defined, traceable, and aligned with project objectives.

title: The 6 Steps of the RE Process
instruction: Select the icons to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the plus icon followed by the next arrow to find out more.

_items.title: Elictation
_items.body:
Requirements elicitation is a critical phase in the Requirements Engineering (RE) process, aimed at gathering and clarifying requirements from stakeholders, such as clients, users, and project team members. Here are the tasks of the elicitation process:

Tasks:

  • Identification of stakeholders
  • Identification of additional sources of requirements
  • Gathering of raw requirements

_items.title: Negotiation
_items.body:
Negotiation is a crucial step in the requirements elicitation process of Requirements Engineering (RE). It involves discussions and compromises among stakeholders to resolve conflicts, align diverse perspectives, and reach a consensus regarding the gathered requirements. Here's are the different tasks of the negotiation step:

  • Identification of the concrete requirements
  • Structuring of the requirements
  • Refinement of the requirements
  • From raw requirements to detailed
  • Requirements sufficient that can be the basis of an acceptance test
  • Identification of dependencies
  • Detection of inconsistencies
  • Resolution of inconsistencies
  • Prioritization of requirements

_items.title: Documentation
_items.body:
In the documentation phase of Requirements Engineering (RE), several key activities are undertaken to capture, record, and organize the gathered requirements effectively. These activities are essential for maintaining clarity, traceability, and communication throughout the software development process. Here's what typically happens during the documentation phase:

  • Specification of requirements
  • Documentation of intermediate results and assumptions
  • Documentation of reasoning for requirements
  • Assignment of attributes to requirements

_items.title: Validation
_items.body:
In the validation phase of Requirements Engineering (RE), the focus is on assessing and confirming that the gathered requirements are complete, accurate, consistent, and aligned with the needs and expectations of stakeholders. Here are the key activities that typically occur during the validation phase of RE:

  • Validation of the content of the specification documents
  • If possible, a formal verification of the documents
  • Verification and validation against previously existing documents (e.g., request for proposals, documentation of a legacy system) and customer wishes

_items.title: Change Management
_items.body:
Change management in Requirements Engineering (RE) is a critical phase that deals with handling and controlling changes to the requirements throughout the software development project. Here's what typically happens in the change management phase of RE:

  • Management of change requests
  • Management of different versions of requirements
  • Each change to a requirement yields a new version
  • Well organized propagation of changes

_items.title: Tracing
_items.body:
Tracing is the process of establishing and maintaining links or relationships between various artifacts and elements throughout the requirements lifecycle. The primary purpose of tracing is to ensure that all requirements are well-documented, consistently managed, and effectively tracked from their origins to their implementation and testing. Here's what happens in the tracing process:

  • Record assumptions
  • Record decisions
  • Record which assumptions lead to which decisions and how the requirements were influenced

title: Video

title: Lecture Content
body:
Welcome to the second lecture of our Requirements Engineering course, where we comprehensively explore the critical elements that define software systems, their surroundings, and the diverse requirements that govern their existence. In this session, we've divided the lecture into four distinct parts:

1. System Context
We will begin by examining the broader context in which software systems operate. Understanding the environment and stakeholders surrounding a system is essential to grasp its purpose and relevance.

2. System Boundary
The system boundary acts as the perimeter that defines what's inside and what's outside, allowing us to focus on the core functionalities and interactions within.

3. Context Boundary
Beyond the system lies the context boundary, a crucial distinction that separates the system from its external environment. Here, we'll explore how this boundary influences requirements and project scope.

4. Types of Requirements
To round off our journey, we will delve into the requirements that drive software projects. We'll shed light on the critical elements that shape the software development landscape from functional to non-functional.

Throughout this lecture, we will unravel the complexities and intricacies of these concepts, providing you with the knowledge and tools necessary to navigate the world of Requirements Engineering effectively. So, let's dive into the depths of system context, boundaries, and requirements and discover how they lay the foundation for successful software development.

title: New Component Title
body: In this part of the lecture, we'll explore the broader ecosystem in which software systems operate. Understanding this context is important to defining the purpose and significance of a system. By the end of this part, you'll know how system context sets the stage for gathering and defining requirements, ensuring that software projects align seamlessly with the needs and expectations of their environment and stakeholders.

title: Video
instruction: Select the play button to start the video.

title: Lecture Content
body:
Requirements Elicitation is the initial process of gathering, defining, and documenting the needs, expectations, and constraints of stakeholders for a software system or project. It is a crucial aspect of practical requirements management within the broader context of software development or project management. The lecture on elicitation is divided into two parts. In the first part, we will cover the following topics:

1. Introduction
In this opening video, we'll address the complexities and challenges associated with gathering accurate and complete information from stakeholders. Understanding why getting the correct information can be tricky is crucial as it lays the foundation for the entire elicitation process. We'll discuss the importance of clear communication, managing expectations, and the impact of misunderstandings in the requirements-gathering phase.

2. Requirement Sources
This video delves into the various sources from which requirements emerge.  Understanding where requirements originate is critical to ensuring a comprehensive and inclusive elicitation process. We'll explore how to identify and prioritise these sources, ensuring that no valuable requirement goes unnoticed.

3. Elicitation Techniques: Elicitation techniques are the tools and methods we use to effectively extract requirements from stakeholders and sources. This video will dive deep into various elicitation techniques, such as interviews, workshops, brainstorming sessions, and use cases. 

4. Survey Techniques
Surveys are a valuable means of collecting structured information from various stakeholders. In this video, we'll explore survey techniques, discuss how to design effective surveys, distribute them, and analyse the gathered data. 

5. Creativity Techniques
Creativity techniques can be a game-changer in requirements elicitation, fostering innovative solutions and uncovering latent needs. In this video, we'll explore techniques like mind mapping, brainstorming, and the Delphi method, which encourage stakeholders to think outside the box.

title: Lecture Content
body:
In the first part of the lecture on requirements elicitation, we covered why this is an essential step of the RE process and introduced some techniques. In this part, we will cover some additional practices and summarise the critical points of this lecture.

6. Document-Centric Techniques
Documents often hold valuable information, and document-centric techniques allow us to extract requirements from existing documentation, such as user manuals, project reports, and contracts. This video'll discuss how to effectively review and analyse documents to uncover implicit requirements, dependencies, and constraints.

7. Observation Techniques
Sometimes, stakeholders may not be able to articulate their needs or may not even be aware of them. In such cases, observation techniques come to the rescue. In this video, we'll explore the power of direct observation, contextual inquiry, and ethnographic studies in understanding user behaviour, pain points, and requirements within their natural environments.

8. Support Techniques and Summary
To wrap up our series, we'll touch on support techniques that can enhance the effectiveness of your elicitation efforts. These include tools, templates, and software solutions to streamline requirements gathering. Finally, we'll summarise the key takeaways from our series on Requirements Elicitation, highlighting the critical role it plays in project success and providing guidance on applying these techniques in your projects.

title: New Component Title
body: Requirements elicitation is the first step of the requirements analysis process. We will cover what this process entails and what different techniques you can use to elicit requirements.

title: New Component Title
body: Elicitation is a core activity of the Requirements Engineering process, and with good elicitation, requirements might be correct or missing. There are many techniques for requirements elicitation, and you have to select the most fitting technique(s) depending on the project. Usually, a combination of multiple techniques yields the best results.

title: Video

title: Lecture Content
body:
The second phase of the requirements engineering process is negotiation. In Requirements Engineering (RE), negotiation refers to the process of collaboratively and iteratively discussing, clarifying, and refining requirements with various stakeholders to reach a consensus on what a software system or product should accomplish. It plays a crucial role in the refinement phases of the requirements engineering process.

1. Introduction 
First, we will begin with an exploration of the foundational concepts of negotiation itself. We will uncover what negotiation entails, its importance in the requirements engineering domain, and the fundamental principles that govern this critical process.

2. Conflict Management
Within the negotiation landscape, conflict often arises as a challenge. We will dedicate a significant portion of our lecture to conflict management to navigate conflict. You will learn practical strategies and techniques to defuse tensions, manage disagreements, and harness the power of constructive conflict resolution to drive requirements engineering projects forward effectively.

3. Summary
To conclude our lecture, we will provide a comprehensive summary of key takeaways from our discussion on negotiation in requirements engineering.

title: Team
body:
This course is taught by Prof. Dr. Benjamin Leiding, M.Sc. Anant Sujatanagarjuna and B.Sc. Nisha Muthuraju from the Clausthal University of Technology. They are working at the Emerging Technologies for the Circular Economy (ETCE) Lab. 

The research of the ETCE Lab is focused mainly on:

  • Intersection of IT and sustainability
  • Circular Economy
  • Self-organized, decentralized and distributed systems
  • Machine-to-Everything Economy (M2X Economy)

Other courses that we teach:

  • Emerging Technologies for the Circular Economy
  • IoT and Digitalization for Circular Economy 
  • The Limits to Growth â€“ Sustainability and the Circular Economy

If you want to find out more about our work, you can visit the ETCE website (Link) to find what we are currently working on, the openly accessible material for all of our courses and a list of theses and project topics.

title: New Component Title
body: In the video, you can find out a little bit more about our research in action.

title: Course Content and Learning Goals
body:
In the "Requirements Engineering" course, you will learn about:

  • Core terminology and core tasks of requirements engineering
  • Requirements engineering process
  • Elicitation techniques
  • Documentation methods
  • Textual, model-based and formal requirements specification
  • Requirements negotiation
  • Requirements Management
  • Traceability
  • Requirements validation and quality assurance

By the end of the course, you will have achieved the following learning goals:

  • Core terminology and core tasks of requirements engineering
  • Understanding of the requirements engineering process
  • Ability to choose, justify and apply appropriate methods and techniques for each step of the requirements engineering process given project constraints and properties

title: Course Organization
body:
Online Format: This course will be entirely online, which means that you won't need to physically attend any in-person classes. All course materials, including lectures, reading materials, assignments, and assessments, will be accessible online.

Prerecorded Videos: Instead of live lectures, the course content will be delivered primarily through prerecorded video presentations. These videos have been created in advance by the instructor and will be available for you to watch at your own pace. You can rewind, pause, or replay them as needed to grasp the material effectively.

Asynchronous Learning: The course is asynchronous, which means there are no fixed lecture times that you have to attend. You can access the course materials and complete assignments based on your own schedule. This flexibility allows you to manage your study time around your other commitments.

Independent Learning: With the asynchronous format, you will have the opportunity to engage in independent learning. However, it's essential to manage your time effectively and stay on track with course deadlines, as assignments and assessments will have due dates.

Discussion and Support: While the course is asynchronous, we will provide Q&A sessions for communication and support. We will meet for exercise/ Q&A sessions to discuss the course content with you, tutorials related to the exercises and to answer any questions you might still have. You can find more information below.

You will be able to find all content on this website. You can find the asynchronous learning material here and we will link the live lectures and slides here. Additionally, all slides can be found on Github (Link). 

Live Lecture
Monday 2:15 pm to 3:45 pm (Berlin time) â€“ on the 30.10.2023
Location: Goslar Gotec (Am Stollen 19 C, 38640 Goslar, Germany) or via BigBlueButton (Link)

Exercise / Q&A
Mondays, 4 pm to 5:30 pm (Berlin time) â€“ 30.11.2023 to 12.02.2024
Location: Goslar Gotec (Am Stollen 19 C, 38640 Goslar, Germany) or via BigBlueButton (Link)

Further questions? Write us an email: etce-re@tu-clausthal.de â† We will only respond to emails written to this specific email address!

title: Exercise and Exam
body:
Exercise

Organization of the exercise:

  • Individual work â†’ no group submissions
  • Multiple-Choice or practical tasks
  • 7-14 days to submit (depending on the task)
  • Submission deadline is always Wednesday at 1:59pm (right before the next lecture)
  • Submission of each exercise is mandatory

Bonus task:

  • You may miss/fail one of the regular exercises
  • Submitting AND passing the bonus task substitutes the missed/failed exercise
  • Bonus task will be very difficult â†’ donâ€™t â€œplanâ€ with the bonus task. Rather submit and pass the regular exercises.

Exam

Prerequisites for admission to the final exam (all criteria have to be fulfilled):

  • Successful completion of the compulsory seven exercises
  • You pass an exercise if you score 50% (or more)
  • You have to submit every exercise

title: New Component Title
body: The Requirements Engineering (RE) process typically consists of several key steps, which can vary in their exact sequence depending on the methodology or framework being used. These six steps in the RE process help organizations gather, analyze, document, validate, verify, and manage requirements effectively, ensuring that software projects align with stakeholders' needs and expectations while minimizing risks and changes during the development lifecycle. The process can be iterative, and feedback loops may exist between these steps to accommodate evolving project needs.

title: Lecture Content
body:
Welcome to our in-depth exploration of "Documentation" as part of the Requirements Engineering process. In total, we will have two full lectures (L05 and L06) to discuss the importance of the documentation step, what different steps it entails and what tools and models exist to help you during this process. This first part of lecture L05 focuses more generally on giving you an introduction to the topic. It is structured into four subparts, each offering a nuanced perspective.

1. Introduction and Documentation in General: This segment initiates our discussion by delving into the multifaceted relationship between documentation and requirements. The emphasis is on establishing a foundational understanding of documentation within the broader requirements engineering process.

2. Criteria for Good Requirements: This section dissects the criteria that demarcate high-quality from low-quality requirements. We will introduce the most important characteristics of reasonable requirements and give you examples for each to make it easier to understand them.

3. Document Structure: How should a document be structured? We will discuss this in the next section, which includes a comprehensive breakdown of document elements and their respective roles in precisely conveying requirements.

4. Document Templates and Summary: In the final subchapter, we introduce the practical utility of document templates. We delve into how templates provide a standardised framework, ensuring consistency and completeness across diverse projects. The first part of lecture L05 concludes with a summary of key insights from this lecture.

title: Impressum
body:
This content was developed by the Emerging Technologies for the Circular Economy Lab (ETCE LAB) at Clausthal University of Technology, Germany. 

The course is modeled and built based on the book "Requirements Engineering â€“ Fundamentals, Principles and Techniques" (link) by Klaus Pohl. Special thanks to Prof. Dr. Steffen Herbold and Dr. Christian Bartelt, who provided valuable input in the form of the teaching materials of their requirements engineering courses.

We are committed to make all of our teaching material available to the public. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License. Feel free to use it for your own purposes. Please share it widely.

title: Lecture Content
body:
Welcome to our in-depth exploration of "Documentation" as part of the Requirements Engineering process. In total, we will have two full lectures (L05 and L06) to discuss the importance of the documentation step, what different steps it entails and what tools and models exist to help you during this process. During this second part of lecture L05, we will discuss textual requirements specification, the challenges of ambiguity, the importance of guidelines and syntactic requirements patterns.

1. Textual Requirements Specification: Textual requirements specification involves expressing system requirements using natural language, providing a narrative description of the desired functionality. This method allows for a comprehensive and flexible articulation of requirements but can present challenges related to clarity and precision.

2. Ambiguity During Requirements Documentation: Ambiguity poses a significant challenge during requirements documentation, as unclear or imprecise language can lead to misinterpretations, misunderstandings, and potential pitfalls in system development. Addressing ambiguity is crucial to ensure that all stakeholders share a common and precise understanding of the requirements, mitigating the risk of errors and enhancing the overall quality of the process.

3. Importance of Guidelines: Guidelines play a pivotal role in overcoming the challenges of ambiguity in requirements documentation. They provide a framework for precise, consistent, and unambiguous expression of requirements. Adhering to guidelines can enhance the quality and effectiveness of requirements documentation and minimise the likelihood of misinterpretations.

4. Syntactic Requirements Patterns: Syntactic requirements patterns involve using structured language constructs or templates to enhance the clarity and consistency of requirements specifications. These patterns provide a standardised way of expressing standard requirements, reducing ambiguity and promoting a systematic approach to documentation.

title: Lecture Content
body:
Welcome to our in-depth exploration of "Documentation" as part of the Requirements Engineering process. In total, we have two full lectures (L05 and L06) to discuss the importance of the documentation step, what different steps it entails and what tools and models exist to help you during this process. This first part of lecture L06 focuses more generally on giving you an introduction to the topic of documentation models and introducing you to some different types of models.

1. Introduction and Models in General
Documentation models are structured frameworks or representations used to document and communicate information about a system, process, or project. They provide a systematic way to capture and organize details related to various aspects of the subject, such as requirements, design, functionality, and interactions.

2. Goal Models
Goal models focus on representing the objectives or goals of a system. They help stakeholders understand the overarching purpose and desired outcomes of the system.

3. Use Cases
Use case models depict different scenarios or interactions between users and a system. They are particularly useful for understanding system behavior from an end-user perspective.

4. Data, Functional, and Behavioral Perspectives
These perspectives provide different viewpoints for documenting system requirements. The data perspective focuses on how data is managed, the functional perspective outlines system operations, and the behavioral perspective describes how the system responds to stimuli.

5. Agent-Oriented Modeling (AOM)
Agent-oriented models center around the concept of intelligent agents, representing entities that can autonomously make decisions and interact with their environment. These models are often used in systems with distributed and autonomous components.

title: Lecture Content
body:
Requirements validation is like ensuring that the instructions for building something make sense and will result in what you want. It's checking to ensure there are no mistakes or missing pieces in the plan before you start building. It's a crucial step in ensuring that what you plan to develop is exactly what you need and expect.

1. Introduction and Requirements Validation in General
In this opening section, we'll explore why validation is a crucial step in the process, understanding its role in ensuring the gathered requirements are accurate, complete, and aligned with the stakeholders' expectations. This introduction lays the foundation for comprehensively exploring the principles and techniques of validating requirements.

2. Principles of Requirements Validation
Moving into the principles of requirements validation, we discuss the fundamental concepts that guide this crucial process. This section addresses the core principles that underpin effective validation, such as clarity, consistency, completeness, and traceability. Understanding these principles is essential for establishing a robust foundation for validating requirements and ensuring they are free from ambiguities, discrepancies, and omissions.

3. Validation Techniques
With a solid understanding of the principles, we shift our focus to the practical aspect of Requirements Validation by exploring various validation techniques. This section covers a spectrum of methods employed in the validation process, including but not limited to reviews, inspections, walkthroughs, prototyping, and simulation. Each technique brings a unique approach to uncovering issues and validating different aspects of requirements, contributing to a comprehensive validation process.

4. Summary
As we near the conclusion of our exploration, the Summary section distils the key insights and takeaways from the lecture on Requirements Validation. We revisit the significance of validation in ensuring the quality and reliability of requirements. The summary encapsulates the principles and techniques covered, providing a concise yet comprehensive overview of the critical aspects discussed throughout the lecture. This synthesis serves as a valuable reference point for understanding validation's pivotal role in the Requirements Engineering process.

title: New Component Title
body: Validation requirements are crucial because they catches problems early, avoiding more significant issues later in the project. Think of it as ensuring the foundation is strong before building the rest of the houseâ€”it sets the stage for a successful and reliable software development journey.

title: New Component Title
body: The documentation step is like writing down the plan before you build something. It's essential because it helps everyone understand what needs to be done and how. Without clear documentation, you might end up with something unexpected. Good documentation makes sure everyone is on the same page and helps the project stay organised and successful.

title: Lecture Content
body:
Imagine the traceability process like connecting the dots in a big picture. It's a way to show how different parts of a project link together. In simple terms, it helps us understand where everything comes from, how it's connected, and what happens to it as the project unfolds. This process is crucial for tracking requirements, their origins, and how they evolve over time, helping everyone involved stay on the same page and ensuring that the project progresses in the right direction.

1. Introduction and Traceability
Requirements traceability involves the capacity to track and describe the entire lifespan of a requirement. This encompasses both forward and backward directions, starting from its origin, progressing through development and specification, to its deployment and utilisation, and through continuous refinement and iteration across all these phases.

2. Classification
in this section, we will discuss different classifications of traceability. Pre-traceability involves establishing relationships from requirement artefacts to aspects in four context facets: subject, usage, IT system, and development. Post-traceability focuses on relationships between requirement artefacts and their successor artefacts, capturing the evolution of project elements. Traceability among requirements includes connections such as refinement, generalisation, or replacement between conditions, providing a comprehensive understanding of their interrelationships.

3. Documentation
Documenting traces is a vital step in maintaining a comprehensive record of requirement relationships. Different types of atoms can be reported using techniques such as textual references, which describe connections in written form, hyperlinks that provide digital shortcuts, traceability models offering visual representations, matrices for structured overviews, and graphs for intuitive depictions. These methods ensure that the complex web of relationships between requirements is well-documented and easily accessible, facilitating effective traceability in the Requirements Engineering process.

4. Summary
Traceability is crucial as it enables the analysis and understanding of relationships among requirements, their sources, and development artefacts. It is a foundation for various activities and is especially valuable during maintenance. For instance, it allows the analysis of the impact of requirement changes, a task essential for ensuring that modifications do not inadvertently affect other parts of the project. While maintaining robust traceability can be challenging, it is pivotal in enhancing overall project understanding and supporting activities that ensure the project's coherence and effectiveness. Utilising tools for traceability can streamline this intricate process, making it more manageable and efficient.

title: New Component Title
body: Traceability is like making sure all the pieces fit together in a big puzzle. It's an important step because it helps us see the connections between different parts of a project. It ensures that nothing is missing, and everything works smoothly, making the entire project come together successfully.

title: Lecture Content
body:
Change management in the Requirements Engineering (RE) process involves handling modifications or updates to the initially defined requirements. There are many reasons for why requirments may change during a project: number/scope of requirements and further information, expected product lifetime, rate of changes to requirements and related docs, number of stakeholders, etc. Changes are not inherently negative, they may even be necessary. But it is important to not loose sight of what requirents have changed and why. In this step, you will learn how to manage these changed during the project. 

1. Introduction and Managing Requirements
When you're working on a project and discover something needs to changeâ€”maybe a new feature is needed or a requirement wasn't clearâ€”change management kicks in. It includes processes for evaluating the impact of the change, understanding how it affects other parts of the project, and deciding whether to accept or reject the change. It's a crucial part of keeping the project flexible and responsive to evolving needs.

2. Change Management
Change management is necessary to properly structure and process change requests for requirements. This structured process leads to justifiable decisions if and how requests are approved.

3. Summary
Managing requirements for complex projects is crucial because these requirements can change during the project. Change management is the structured process of handling these changes. It involves a Change Control Board that evaluates and decides whether to approve or reject changes. Dealing with change requests is a whole process on its own to ensure that adjustments are made smoothly and don't disrupt the overall project.

title: New Component Title
body: Change management is like having a plan for when things in your project need to change. It's important because, during a project, things might not always go as initially planned. Change management helps everyone stay on the same page when adjustments are needed. It's a bit like having a flexible roadmapâ€”if you discover a better route or need to make a detour, change management guides how to do it without causing confusion or problems. This step ensures that everyone in the team knows about and agrees on the changes, making the project smoother and more successful in the end.

title: Lecture Content
body:
Our last lecture will discuss the importance and possible pitfalls of using tools during the Requirements Engineering process. These tools assist in capturing, analysing, documenting, and tracking requirements throughout the project lifecycle. 

1. Introduction and Tool Support in General
Tools are pivotal in modernising and optimising various processes, and Requirements Engineering (RE) is no exception. They facilitate capturing, analysing, documenting, and tracking requirements, contributing to a more streamlined and effective management process.

2. Requirements Management Tools
Different tools exist that may be used for varying purposes. It may be possible to reuse tools from system development, or visualisation tools can support brainstorming sessions or depict processes and workflows.

3. Introducing and Evaluating Tools
Before introducing tools, it is important to have existing processes that they can support. There may be different challenges while introducing tools, so it is important to consider them and discuss these implementations with all stakeholders. Evaluating these tools from different views is also vital. 

4. Summary
During the RE process, various tools are accessible and categorised as specialised or general-purpose tools. Recognising that a sound process precedes the choice of tools is crucial, emphasising that the tool's suitability hinges on alignment with the strategy. Introducing new tools should undergo a pilot phase, as evaluating them is a time-consuming yet necessary endeavour for ensuring their efficacy and compatibility with the established RE framework.

----

5. Course Summary
As we conclude the Requirements Engineering, we will briefly summarise the whole course, highlighting the most crucial insights and providing an overview of the key concepts covered. This summary is a culmination of exploring the intricacies of managing requirements and leveraging tools for effective project outcomes.

title: New Component Title
body: Tools should be used at different stages of the Requirements Engineering process.

title: Impressum
body:
This content was developed by the Emerging Technologies for the Circular Economy Lab (ETCE LAB) at Clausthal University of Technology, Germany. 

The course is modeled and built based on the book "Requirements Engineering â€“ Fundamentals, Principles and Techniques" (link) by Klaus Pohl. Special thanks to Prof. Dr. Steffen Herbold and Dr. Christian Bartelt, who provided valuable input in the form of the teaching materials of their requirements engineering courses.

We are committed to make all of our teaching material available to the public. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License. Feel free to use it for your own purposes. Please share it widely.

title: Exercise
body:
Published on: 27.11.202

Deadline: 11.12.2023 â€“ 2:59 pm

Submission location: Moodle Course Page â†’ Excercise 02 (Link)

Task(s):

Submission guidlines:

  • max. 3 pages
  • Please upload a valid PDF file.
  • Please review and finalise your submission once you have uploaded all files and then click the Submit button.

Scenario: Your company has been tasked with the development of a university information system for teaching, learning and research. and research (Hochschulinformationssystem fÃ¼r Lehre, Studium und Forschung (LSF)). It offers options for recording, managing and displaying courses and research projects as well as the associated resources (facilities, people, rooms). The LSF is used as a study information, course management and planning system, so that different user groups can be effectively supported in their specific planning activities. Moreover,  students can plan their studies more easily, and may use the system to access study and examination information.

Task(s):

  1. Identify and list the relevant project stakeholders.
  2. Identify three applicable elicitation techniques and briefly list advantages/disadvantages in the context of the given scenario.
  3. Prepare an interview with ten questions (choosing any one of your listed stakeholders) following the guidelines outlined in the elicitation lecture.
  4. What are the advantages and disadvantages of the interview elicitation approach? What could be a complementary approach?
